One thing that most helicopter instructors (young or old-er) don’t know or won’t tell their students is that pedal control is way more important than most realize. Every time you allow your heading to change, intentionally or otherwise (“otherwise” being what the newbies are doing), the cyclic then, which is the most touchy/difficult control then has to be adjusted for that change. You could greatly reduce that need by simply having better pedal control, which is an easier control to master and will make all of your hovering much more smooth and controlled.
So, for a nickels worth of free advice, focus on rock solid pedal control.

I was trained in a Hiller UH12c and later a Bell 47. These helicopters had a rod connecting the collective to the throttle lever. It was just a hit and miss as far as correlation between collective and rotor rpm was concerned. The outboard throttle being used was as active as any dirt bike. Rotor rpm was a constant work load. These new helicopters use a computer to  maintain rotor speed just like a turbine. Twist the throttle wide open lock the collective and it is as easy as flying an airplane. You need to get into a Korean war aged  chopper to really get the feel of the machine. We had many pilots that were trained in modern helicopters and they could not fly the 47.

Pedal turns to this old rotor head. More or less. Excellent. New stuff seems more familiar. Like the six main instruments in a turbine. And if course many scary things designed to scare you to death. Including the JESUS nut! I remember alot but my TBI took a bunch of a bunch of years. Anyway great video

Waaay back in flight school, after learning the basics in the T-34, we headed to Whiting Field for rotary wing training in TH-57s.  The instructors would take us to outlying fields near Milton, where large squares were painted on the ground.  I can't remember any student winning that 'case of beer' from the instructor if they could keep the bird in the box on the first try.  But bit by bit over a period of a couple of hours....cyclic-collective-pedals...and in that order and one on top of the other...it finally clicks.  Nothing was more satisfying than after moving on from this stair step training and additional knowledge, to actually look forward to full auto rotations from altitude, cut guns while in an air taxi.  Nr is LIFE!!!  So much energy stored in the (rotating) head.  That knowledge confirmed when after shooting a full autorotation, engine still at idle, and the instructor has you THEN pick the bird up into a five foot hover.  Best when done on a cooler day when you don't have a full bag of gas...but it could be done.  Awesome memories.

The easy way to get the right mindset is to think of all the power from the engine when in a hover as a dollar bill.  Every control pressure or movement if like drawing some of that dollar and putting it on the control.  If you have more than a dollar, you rise, and less than a dollar makes you sink.  Putting a few pennies into the tail rotor by pressing the pedal makes you turn away from the direction that the main rotor is turning, but those pennies have to come from somewhere, either the collective or the cyclic.  When you ease pressure, those pennies have to GO somewhere.  Always a dollar.  When you are able to start thinking what you want to do, and where that power will come from, you are able to reach a stable hover anytime you need to.

Using Microsoft Flight Simulator 2004, augmented with a Flight-Link G-Stick3 cyclic, a Flight- Link collective lever with twist-grip throttle, along with Saitek rudder pedals serving as anti-torque pedals, it took me way more than 8 cumulative hours to perfect the subtle, almost imperceptible cyclic and anti-torque pedal interaction that comprises a stable hover in the virtual Robinson R22 trainer.

A while back a qualified helicopter pilot commented in an online forum that mastering the hover in a desk-top flight simulator can take a fair bit longer than learning the same skill in a real helicopter, because a stationary simulator cannot not replicate the seat-of-the-pants inner-ear feedback that is present in full-motion rotary-wing simulators, and in actual aircraft.

I therefore make bold to boast that I could bring any helicopter to a rock-stable hover in seconds, PROVIDED that I use my RIGHT hand for the cyclic, with my left for the collective. Hey, hire me. Bring her up to flight idle, and I'll fly you there for fifty bucks an hour negotiable.

I had an rc helicopter, hovering the thing was so hard, it,s trying to spin counter clockwise so you're giving it tail rotor to balance it. But when it's on the ground friction holds it back by varying amounts depending on how much thrust it has, then the thing is so light that the wind is trying to carry it away, so you're giving it collective input to hold it in place at the same time. When I first started really trying to do more than a low hover I still remember when it was facing me high in the air hovering and a large gust of wind quickly took it away, I gave it a lot of cyclic to try and bring it back, problem, I pulled the cyclic towards me in a panic(where I wanted it to go, towards me, lol), but obviously it accelerated more because it's tail was pointing away, unfortunately it got stuck in a high tree because it just happened too fast to correct, it was fine but it was something that I had to practice getting my head around. Right after learning to hover, be aware of where it will go based on it's orientation relative to myself and try to avoid large cyclic movement if possible because it can go dang fast! I do believe a real helicopter would be easier in that respect because I am always facing the same way as the helicopter and without a collective I was dealing with throttle delay as well, plus I'd have killed to have my hands on collective and cyclic alone and pedals for the tail rotor, seems easier to me but I will never get to try the real thing :-(

It depends on the design of the rotor system and the basic and inherent stability of the helicopter. When Lockheed was building prototypes for what became the Cheyenne helicopter that was tested back in the late sixties early seventies. They had one that went down due to a problem several miles away from the Homebase. A mechanic went out to work on the helicopter, and instead of waiting for the pilot to come and fly it back he flew it back. Because of mechanisms that they built into the helicopter that made it inherently stable. So that you didn't have to have an electronic system to constantly trim the aircraft and keep it stable like Bell Helicopter does.

Think of collective as all the main rotor blades collectively increasing the angle of attack at once. When you said the tail rotor pushing the whole aircraft to the side is partially incorrect. As you stated it provides counter torque which is true yes. But only for the tail pushing in the opposite direction of the rotation of the main transmission. Not the entire aircraft as you stated. That prevents the aircraft from spinning in circles due to the torque of the main transmission/gearbox. The pedals allow you to rotate the aircraft 360°. The collective provides lift by increasing the AOA. The cyclic increases the AOA of only 1 main rotor blade at 90° in the direction of cyclic travel. Which every blade that approaches the 90° mark will increase aoa then drop back down to less of a degree till it reaches the 90 degree mark again. That goes for all the blades that hits that 90° mark. Which if you push forward om the cyclic ot will allow the bird to tilt the nose, pull back the bird will tilt slightly backward and the to right or left will start to roll the bird.

My dad flew radio controlled airplanes for about 45 years including one helicopter for around 20+ years. He competed in events regularly. At the three radio control clubs he belong to he was also one of the test pilot instructors. I never will forget the first day he flew the helicopter. I think the entire club showed up because nobody at that time had one. Everybody clapped and cheered after the helicopter lifted off the ground. My dad had a real knack for hand eye coordination and responding in a nanosecond. A couple of flights later on the same day he flew the helicopter away from the viewing area for safety sake. Then he put the helicopter to the test. He got the helicopter spinning around on its vertical axis and then pulled up and flew upside down inverted while he flew it around the field. As he came around the turn at the end of the field he right sided the helicopter for a high speed pass down the center of the field. Needless to say when he landed he got a standing ovation. It was quite a sight to see. He tried many times to explain the physics of a helicopter to me and the principles of a gyroscope. And how different flying his model helicopter was compared to his airplanes. He had a knack for it that’s for sure. He is gone now - we have so many fond memories of his flying.

I had the chance to fly a commercial heli simulator when doing research for my bachelor's thesis. I knew which steering input controlled which motion, and I knew about the interlinking (do you say so?) between the axes and their movements. Yet it took about 10 seconds until we lay upside-down, on the rotor, about 8 m away from where we started.

I have a helo add on to my Pilot's license.  I have hovered Bell 47, Huey, Enstrom, R-22,  2 different Baby Belle, Rotorway and I think a Hughes 269 (I was never sure the CFI was entirely off the controls) and two ultra light (254#) helicopters.  The very easiest to hover was the ultra light ships.  The very worst was the R-22.  It seems the cyclic control feedback on the R-22 was nearly non existent. Even after more than 400 hrs helo time, I still want a CFI on board for my hovering in an R-22.

2 things that help: No bands. The assisting bands make the controls numb. Every input induces a moment. You need to counter every moment with another input/moment. They aren't like fixed wing aircraft with dihedral to the wings that lead to the craft having some self stabilization effect; helicopters just keep moving in the direction you pushed them until you counter that movement.

As it happens, it is kind of the same with a racecar. It's not just left-right with the steering wheel, and accelerate-brake with the pedals. It's more. It may sound counter-intuitive, but to take corners at the best possible speed involves a careful use of both pedals syncronized with your steering input. If you're going fast enough, you won't have enough grip in the tires to turn (understeer), and you have to minimize that using the weight transfer of the car. That's the key. You control the car by shifting weight on the suspension system so that you use as much grip as possible. And that weight transfer is achieved through steering and pedal input.

That’s the beauty in them. Most of the time it’s the opposite. They look easy but it’s hard. With a cube, you learn about 7 different “algorithms” aka patterns, and then all you do is repeat the same algorithms and it’ll eventually solve the cube no matter how much it’s mixed up.

It was always funny back in Highschool, kids thinking if they took it and mixed it up really really good- that I couldn’t possibly know how to solve it then. But nope nope nope easy A every time :O

Moral of my short story is to maybe learn how to solve it yourself viewers! They’re fun to learn and they blow people away when you whip out a quick solve at someone’s house. I think I’ve gotten myself laid this way loolllllllll

One of the biggest monsters that can bite new Heli pilots is dynamic rollover. New pilots often have a tendency to get very light on the skids and linger there without smartly pulling the collective and getting the machine fully into the air. Same thing can happen on landing. Having just the tip of landing skid in contact with the ground is dangerous territory - especially for a new pilot.

This is very interesting. I was in Scotland a few months ago in a large rented camper van, 30' long, 8' wide; trying to drive it on roads that were about 9' wide, and almost randomly varying in width, with sharp dropoffs at the edge of the pavement. My son was the passenger. He was freaking out, I did everything I could to keep from taking off the mirrors. It didn't turn out well, I took off a mirror on a bus sticking out into the road when an oncoming car swerve just over the centerline. Then my son took over. He's a better but less experienced driver than me. I'd made some really basic errors, like not looking farther down the road to drive straight (this is like your pilot induced oscillations). So he took over driving. What I quickly noticed was that sitting in that front passenger seat was scary. Short front on the Fiat truck body. As he'd done for me, I could look into the side mirror and see the white line at the edge of the road. What I'd figured out to do was ONLY tell him when he was good, about 6-12" inside that white line. My goal was to set up a positive feedback loop. Of course if I thought he was really going to hit something I'd say something. Within an hour he had dialed in that edge of the road. Then I would only give positive feedback when he had to squeeze over for oncoming traffic. So my driving problems from him freaking out? Not his fault. It was just a standard driving situation that normal human responses made worse. I got into a negative feedback loop. The biggest issue (after renting a vehicle wider than the roads) was my not looking down the road. The take away was using positive feedback. In a helicopter the instructors have to do what they have to do. But my point is, if possible, look for a way to input only positive feedback. This way your brain gets a little 'ping' when you're doing it right and then that's what you learn.
The term you're looking for is Automaticity. Also, in general women teach skills differently than men, of course everybody is slightly different from everybody else. The point is not to get in some debate, but to find an instructor or teacher who is good at it and then trying to figure out as many things that they are doing that make them good. With teaching people how to use a computer the general tendency of guys was to show you, the women instructors I observed got you to do it. Pretty basic. An experiment with positive and negative feedback loops would probably be interesting. A balancing skill, like maybe slack lining, might be good for this. You'd have to figure out a way to make one balancing skill negative feedback driven, you keep falling off, and a slightly different skill, positive feedback driven: you don't fall off, but get steadier and steadier.

I have an analogy for hovering I'd like to throw out there:
Driving along the motorway you keep in the middle of the lane a constant distance from the car in front. Now add that you have to keep the car a specific height above the motorway and you have to keep it pointing in the right direction. The car will not stay there, it will drift. Now add that if you move any of the controls you have to counteract the reaction with another control.
e.g. say you're too high and move the control to bring it down, your car reacts by turning to the right and starts drifting to the right in the lane, you need to counteract that by turning the wheel left and bring it back to centre... then as you come back to centre, you ease off the control to bring it down and ease off the control to counteract the right turn by which time you've overshot and have to do the opposite to correct the overshoot! Not only that, you were focussing so much on coming down that now you've got too close to the car in front so now you need to correct the overshoot and increase the distance from the car in front which requires its own control and correction...

Car: L/R(1) + A/B(2)
Helicopter: CoU/D(1) + ThO/I(2) + CyF/B(3) + CyL/R(4) + PL/R(5)

Hovering a helicopter is no harder than walking. It takes us years to learn to do it (walk) , but once you do it, you can do it without thinking about it, even when drunk or tired. Making a helicopter an extension of your body also takes much practice, but is also no harder to do than walking.

And yes, everything you do, you are doing with cyclic, collective, throttle, and rudder, but it's the same with walking. If you lean forward while standing, what happens? You start to tip. What do you do? Do you "lean back*? No you take a step which converts the leaning motion, into forward motion. As you step out, your body drops, so you compensate by heel toeing and by moving the other leg in. Need to stop? You begin leaning back and taking shorter steps to bleed off momentum. You balance with your arms as well. Need to turn quickly, the turn starts at your feet, making you fall in a circle, not at your arms or head. So you are doing multiple things at once, to move in a coordinated fashion. Coordinated is key, when you increase collective, you increase rotational resistance, which makes the heli want to piroette, so you apply rudder to compensate for that. It also causes rotor speed to drop, which you apply throttle for, and finally the blip in rudder pushes the entire heli to one side thanks to the tail rotor, so you compensate with a little cyclic input. Moving one requires moving all 4. After doing this awhile though, it's 2nd nature and you don't even think about it. The same way you don't think about every movement of your leg muscles, pelvis, arms, head, and eyes when walking around an obstacle.

Heli instructors can be incredibly brave AND complete idiots. Seriously though, they've obviously learned how to mitigate the risk, as they are (mostly) still alive, and die of other means, usually medical.
You actually DON'T arrive at a Rubik's cube solution "right off the bat". You work portions of the cube using standard patterns for, first, the top 9 cubes, then the middle 9 after the top is solved, etc.
I've heard the heli instructors call the over-control problem "gorilla motions" and that fixed wing pilots are harder to train to fly heli than non-pilots, as the controls are so different, gain wise. For example, on a take off in a tail dragger, you have to almost ANTICIPATE the rudder inputs needed to keep you heading down runway without veering into a ground loop and they are often right to the stop, like a bang bang controller. Trying to go from that to a heli control is pretty radical.
Your "hands nearer the controls" comment reminded me of the "mistakes high" rule of thumb. I'll bet there's also a pretty high gain altitude component working there, ie. nearer the ground, nearer the controls. It occurred to me that someone that intentionally wanted to kill themselves could do so rather easily with this type of controls shown here, there. THAT scared me, bet it's happened. Great vid!

The worst feeling is going from fixed wing to helio and then slowing down when you're still high enough that in a plane you'd drop, crash and die. In fixed wing you avoid "stalling" at all costs. You MUST maintain 60 or 70 mph or you stall, the lift falls off your wings and you drop. In a chopper it is no big thing to come to a stop while you're still a couple hundred feet in the air and every nerve in your body is screaming at you to push forward and get your airspeed up again. It takes several (many) landings like that before the fixed wing training gives way to "Ok .. This is normal and I'm not gonna DIE!"

This is why helicopter training is so much more frustrating than fixed wing training. The very first time you fly a plane you wobbly taxi to the runway, but once you are cleared you give it full throttle and once you get to 60 knots rotate and you are flying. It is that easy. But in a helicopter everything is based on being able to hover. You take off from a hover, you land to a hover, and you reposition with a hover, so until you can hover you cannot fly. Good news is that all of a sudden something clicks in your brain and you can hover. From that point on you cannot remember why it was so hard to learn in the first place!

Tail rotor offsets torque, which is proportional to engine rpm. Proportioning the rotor speed can be done automatically using a simple purely mechanical system, or poorly using primitive manual controls. Cheap helecopters use the latter, because aircraft  in general are expensive,  unreliable POS that need maintenance measured in tens of hours.  If they couldn't be certified for production unless they could  operate reliably for 200 hours AND land safely with an unconscous pilot, you'd see a huge change in design.

Flying a plane is just about as difficult, particularly when you're doing pylon turns where you have to keep the tip of one wing always pointed at the same spot on the ground and fly a near-perfectly-circular path around that point. (Note, I have very little experience, but I still remember what it feels like years after the fact.)

Doing a turn in a plane isn't as simple as just hitting left or right rudder and that's it. If that's all you do, all you're gonna do is make the plane skid at an angle through the air (which is what you're supposed to do if you're flying into a crosswind, mind you). To do a proper turn, you have to turn the yoke to bank into the turn, adjust your rudder slightly to then turn the nose into the turn, all the while you have to pull back slightly on the yoke to rudder up and maintain altitude because when you do a banked turn you also lose momentum because you're accelerating by changing the direction of your flight vector AND the additional drag from the rudder deflection.

And all three of those adjustments need to happen simultaneously and precisely. It's... hard. Just like hovering a helicopter, it takes a few hours with a flight instructor to really make it click.

I had only one or two hours. Not even remotely enough time to make it click for me. But even in that short time, I did get a little bit of a feel for it. It's fun to do, but it bakes your noodle until you get the hang of it. :)

I think what finally made hovering click for me was when my instructor demonstrated that he could hold the position of a hover over the ground just by holding the palm of his open hand stationary on the forward right side of the cyclic, with palm facing towards himself. Once I realized it really was that simple, I stopped overcontrolling and everything kind of fell into place from there. But long after I got decent at hovering, I still had trouble with smooth pick ups and set downs (ESPECIALLY set downs). Those were skills that took me a lot longer to hone than hovering. Some folks learn way faster than others, but one thing I have definitely noticed is that the speed at which you learn the basics has zero correlation with your flying ability several hundred or thousand hours down the road. So to the student pilots out there who are getting discouraged by slow progress, don't give up!

Maintaining a stable hover in a helicopter has been likened to keeping one's balance on a pogo stick in a room whose floor has been strewn with ball bearings.  When I learned to fly helicopters, I found that this description isn't far from the truth.  Unlike airplanes, most helicopters, and especially the Robinson R-22, are inherently unstable.  The beginner tends to overcontrol and not anticipate what the machine will do.  In time, one learns that the control inputs are usually nearly imperceptibly tiny and need to be supplied within a small fraction of a second.

My first stable hover was near the end of my 3rd lesson, if you include my intro flight with my crotchety British instructor yelling at me to, "Quit stirring the pot!", which was his way of describing the cyclic control inputs that initiate a pilot induced oscillation. Was sweating bullets during one our hottest recent summers at a dusty little airport in Northern CA. I had all of 1.5hrs, because my flights could only be about 30min before I was completely saturated, drenched in sweat, and exhausted. My 2mi drive home through one stoplight took all of the focus I had left... But I remember the amazing moment when all four of my limbs decided to cooperate and something just clicked. Never had trouble hovering since, but I could've easily been mistaken as drunk in my earliest attempts. Great video as always, can't imagine anyone more mentally equipped to take on helicopters than you.

I solo flew the R22 after 17 hours. I can't recall how long it took to hover. But when it happened, it was a switch going off and I could "just do it". I guess I took to like a duck to water. My instructor pulled some INSANE stunts on me, like throttle chops on takeoff, over water at really low altitudes. The parallels between heli hover and mountain biking are interesting. If you watch the terrain too close to you, it's a disaster. When you figure out how not to, it comes into focus. Instructors told me back then a LOT of asian students were coming to AZ (I'm in CA), and most didn't solo until about 60 hours (got my license at 70). The vast majority of them would fly the ship right into the ground unless the instructor took over, despite screaming and yelling at them to "flare". Apparently they had a really hard time transferring what they read in class to real world. They would fixate and freeze up. I theorize that what makes that culture so great at math and science is the same thing that makes things like driving and flying so hard. They can focus on one thing really well, but with a car or aircraft you have to do 5 things at once.

For what it's worth, Destin, learning to solve a Rubik's Cube is A LOT easier than most people think. I believe pretty much anyone could learn how to do it, especially a smart guy like you. All you have do is learn a few simple algorithms, and the order in which to use them, which is really very easy. Within a day I bet you could learn to consistently solve any 3x3x3 Rubik's Cube in minutes. Just look up a few videos on it. There are loads out there.

I'd argue that Rubik's Cube can be solved with knowledge alone. With practice you can develop a greater understanding of the cube's mechanics and learn to solve most of it intuitively; it's not necessary, but it is more rewarding, and helps to speed up how fast you can solve it.

When it comes to really fast cubers, they have this understanding, plus they know a lot more algorithms, so their solves are more efficient, and they're faster at recognizing when to use which. On top of that they use finger tricks and high tech cubes that allow them to execute the patterns at around 5-10 turns per second. That's how they get times under 20 and even 10 seconds.

Helicopter Pilots Are Different

"The thing is helicopters are different from airplanes. 
An airplane by it's nature wants to fly, and if not interfered with too strongly by unusual events or incompetent piloting, it will fly.
A helicopter does not want to fly. It is maintained in the air by a variety of forces and controls working in opposition to each other.
And if there is any disturbance in this delicate balance the helicopter stops flying immediately and disastrously.
There is no such thing as a gliding helicopter.
That's why being a helicopter pilot is so different from being an airplane pilot, and why in generality airplane pilots are open, clear-eyed, buoyant, extroverts.
And helicopter pilots are brooders, introspective anticipators of trouble.
They know if something bad has not happened it is about to".

Harry Reasoner - 1977

A great video, but the description of how the controls work could have been a little more clear. Collective changes the pitch on the main rotor blades by an equal (collective) amount. This controls how much lift spinning blades (called a disc) creates. When lift equals weight, the helicopter will remain at a given height. If the lift is greater than the weight, the helicopter will rise, if it is less, it will descend.

The cyclic varies the pitch of the blades throughout each 360 degree revolution (each cycle), and this controls the attitude off the disc. The attitude of the disc tilts the lift in the desired direction- forward to go forward, laterally to move to the side.

For any given amount of lift (force), the helicopter will try to spin in the opposite direction to the rotation of the blades (Newton's third law), and the thrust of the tail rotor can be adjusted with the pedals to generate an equal force in the opposite direction to keep the helicopter straight. Of course as lift (collective) increases, drag increases, and the engine must generate more power to maintain a constant main rotor RPM.

Every helicopter control has primary and secondary effects. The primary effect of collective is altitude, the secondary effects are power (torque), yaw (turning effect) and attitude. The primary effect of cyclic is airspeed, the secondary effect is altitude. The primary effect of pedals is heading (balance) the secondary effect is power (increases with greater pedal input). These all combine to permit a heavier than air aircraft to take off vertically, cruise at 200kmh, then land as gently as a leaf on a tiny helipad. Slow, rough and expensive, but as Igor Sikorsky, the grand daddy of helicopters said, 'helicopters will do a job that no other aircraft can do'.

A little furter explanation about the helicopter control:
The swashplate (a.k.a. ballerina) works by changing the angle of attack on the rotor blades, which are just like wings, only that they generate lift through a circular, in place of linear, motion. Imagine the plate like a rail, and the rotor guide rods, the cart. When you move the cyclic, the plate tilts the swash in the respective direction of the control input. The cart, traveling along the rail, eiter goes uphill or downhill depending on how you set the track. As in, cyclically, the blade which connector rod is traveling along the rail, pivots on it's axis, levered by the connecting rod going up or down on the swashplate track. As it travels, it gradually changes the angle of attack on the blade, making the lift higher where the angle of the blade is higher. the resulting difference in lift generates torque, wich is why the aircraft tilts in the desired direction.
The same goes for the collective, only that it changes the pitch of all blades collectivelly, increasing overall lift and making the craft go up. Just like how the tail rotor works, only in a different application. Also, like an airplane propeller changes it's pitch to optimize engine rpm and the bite it takes of the atmosphere.
You don't actually control the engine directly, it is optimized for a given rpm for better fuel efficiency and safety (as the large diameter of the rotor could make the tip of the blade reach transonic speeds, wich creates turbulence, flutter and may stall the blade, as well of a ton of drag). What happens is that the increase in the angles of attack also increase drag on the blades. And that is where the counterrotating torque comes from.

It seems that helicopter engines are far more reliable than single prop airplanes. Or at least I'd imagine they would have to be. If the engine fails on your C172 you're gliding the thing to a safe, if bumpy landing 99 times out of 100. If the engine fails on a helicopter, there aren't any wings to slow your descent. So my question is why are helicopter engines more reliable? Is it the difference in the engines themselves? Does it have to do with the way in which the engines operate (i.e., stick an airplane engine in a helicopter and it will increase its reliability because of the type of work it has to do, and vice versa)? Is it that the redundancy of the wings on a basic single prop airplane means that the maintenance requirements are lower than those of a helicopter engine? I've always wondered that.
